original_title: Sri Lanka’s stocks close higher on banking and diversified financials
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka stocks closed up on mixed sentiments on Tuesday after domestic bond restructuring assurances and fears on investing in the banking sector diminished, sparking interest in the banking counters due to undervalued share price, an analyst said.

The All Share Price Index (ASPI) edged up 0.63 percent or 68.08 points to 10,796.07, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was up 0.48 percent or 15.08 points to 3,172.00, according to exchange provisional data.

“There is continued interest in the banking sector, because the shares have been down for so long it is undervalued and it still is, which is why the sector is gaining along with the market,” an analyst said.
The market has continuously being seeing gains on domestic debt optimization (DDO) since July 04.

The market generated a turnover of 3.1 billion rupees, majority of the revenue had come from the banking sector brining in 1 billion rupees and the diversified financials sector brought in 465 million rupees.
The banking sector is picking up on domestic debt optimization assurances, while investors are seeking alternative investments bringing up the market on green, an analyst said.
The overall market is moving up on domestic debt optimization assurances, picking up several stock counters in the market.
Top gainers were Commercial Bank, Hatton National Bank, and Ceylinco Insurance.
There was notable interest in the tourism industry followed by Sri Lanka surpassing 700,000 tourism arrivals. (Colombo/July10/2023)
